headline: Kill Gerrymandering With Technology
summary: The national census always leads to a discussion regarding redistricting ("Redistricting and the Health-Care Vote" by Michael Solon, op-ed, March 19) and gerrymandering (Letters, March 8). Technology now affords the possibility of fair, non-partisan redistricting by computer. The program would only identify numbers of citizens and their location, not their political party, gender or race.

headline: Aren't We Entitled To What We Want?
summary: Charles Krauthammer is right when he writes the "debt bomb is looming" as a result of the new "entitlement" bestowed upon the American people ("Notable & Quotable," March 27). One of the realities we face is that the younger generation is often determining the outcome of our elections.

headline: The Test You Use Makes a Difference
summary: In regard to the March 24 Letter "Teaching to the Test Dumbs Down School Standards": If a concept is sufficiently important enough to teach, then it is worth testing.

headline: U.S. Health Care Is Competitive on a Level Field
summary: In his March 26 Letter to the Editor, Curtis J. Krock, M.D., repeats a tired mantra repeatedly cited by supporters of socialized health care: "It is challenging to find a desirable health-care statistic besides cost in which our care significantly exceeds that of our peers."  But data showing superior performance of the U.S. health-care system are abundant.

headline: Commercial Prices  Continue to Gain
summary: An index compiled by Moody's Investors Service found that prices continue to show modest gains following a long two-year slide. The Moody's/REAL Commercial Property Price Index rose 1.0% in January to 114.73, the third consecutive monthly gain. In October 2009, commercial property prices hit a low of 107.98, which was 43.7% below the peak in October 2007. Since then, prices have come back 6.3% and are now down 40.2% from the peak.
